entries.content: Price is rarely the actual reason someone doesn't buy. It's often an excuse or a negotiation tactic.
If a prospect is pathologically cheap and only cares about the lowest price, they will likely be a difficult customer. Consider sending them to a competitor.
Prospects know salespeople are often scared and will use price objections to get discounts, even if they are willing to pay.
Successful salespeople know their value and product's worth; they are not afraid to say no or walk away.
If asked for a discount, don't just give it away. Negotiate: 'We could move on price, but what are we going to get in exchange?'
When faced with a price-only focus: 'I get it, if price is going to be the only factor in which you make this decision, then we're out.'
entries.notes: Delivered with confidence, challenging the premise.

entries.content: Assert position on price: 'We will never be cheapest.'
When asked to tender, ask the prospect: 'Other than price, what's going to be the key determining factor?'
If a prospect insists price is the *only* factor after being challenged, be willing to walk away.
Example of someone trying to give a product away for free but people still wouldn't take it, demonstrating price isn't the barrier.
If you consistently lose deals *only* on price, either you believe prospect lies or you attract the wrong, cheap customers.

focus_area: Handling Price Objections: Reframe to ROI, "Compared to what?", breakdown strategy
